fields.value: Integrated Behavioural and Biological Assessment -I (Karnataka - High Risk Groups)

dsDescriptionValue.value: The Integrated Behavioural and Biological Assessment is a significant component of the overall evaluation strategy of the Avahan programme. The first round of the IBBA was conducted between 2005 to 2006 (for FSWs), 2006-2008 for MSMs, and 2007-2008 for Clients of FSWs in selected districts of Karnataka state of India. The objectives of the IBBA were: a) to measure the major outcomes of HIV interventions funded by Avahan under the India AIDS Initiative; b) to make data available for estimating sizes of populations targeted by the Avahan programme and; c) to make information available to partner organizations under Avahan for modelling the impact of the intervention.

keywordValue.value: Avahan, Clients of FSWs, FSWs, HIV Intervention, HIV prevention, Modelling, MSM, TG; INSTITUTION: University of Manitoba / Karnataka Health Promotion Trust (KHPT); STRATEGIC AREA: Avahan evaluation

fields.value:
The first round of IBBA was conducted in 5 districts from 16 Avahan program implemented districts of Karnataka. The target sample size was 400 per group, per district for FSWs, their clients, high-risk MSM and TG. Overall, a total of 5914 respondents (FSWs: 2277;  MSM: 847; CFSWs: 2790) were covered in IBBA1. Conventional cluster sampling, time-location sampling and respondent driven sampling were the methods used for selection of respondents. The statutory approval for the conduct of IBBA and its protocol is obtained by the Health Ministry's Screening Committee (HSMC), under the auspicious of Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR), New Delhi. Ethical approval for IBBA is obtained from the Institution Ethical Review Board of St. John's Medical college and Hospital, Bangalore, University of Manitoba and Laval University, Canada. Informed consent was taken from the respondents before the administration of questionnaire and sample for biological tests and protection of confidentiality of respondents wa
s given high priority. Intensive training was imparted to all field personnel associated with IBBA. Community preparation was an integral part of IBBA. Independent community advisory boards (CAB) and community monitoring boards (CMB) were formed in each district for each of the survey groups to protect the interest of the survey population.
